title: Should I Hire a Math Tutor? A Parent's Decision Guide
description: How to know when tutoring is needed, what to look for, and alternatives to consider.

content.intro: Tutoring can be transformative – or a waste of money. Here's how to decide if your child needs a tutor, and how to find a good one.

items: Need for one-on-one attention classroom doesn't provide
Specific learning needs or learning differences
Parent unable to provide adequate help

sections.text: When Tutoring Might NOT Be the Answer

items: Parent wants to outsource homework battles
Child is already performing well, parent wants "better"
No commitment from the child to engage

sections.text: What to Look For in a Tutor

items: Assessment of where child is starting
Just does homework with child (no skill building)

sections.text: Ask potential tutors: "How will you assess where my child is? What's your plan to address gaps? How will you measure progress?" Good tutors can answer these clearly.

items: Online video lessons (Khan Academy is free)

faq.question: How long should I try tutoring before seeing results?
faq.answer: Give it 6-8 weeks of consistent sessions. You should see attitude improvement first, then skill improvement. If nothing changes after 3 months, reassess.

faq.question: Can I use tutoring just temporarily?
faq.answer: Absolutely. Tutoring to close a specific gap is often more effective than ongoing tutoring. Establish a goal and work toward it.

faq.question: Should I tell my child's teacher about the tutor?
faq.answer: Yes. Teachers can share what's being worked on in class and coordinate with the tutor. This prevents contradictory methods.
